intro: Rhexia rosmarinoides, commonly known as rosemary mallow, is a herbaceous perennial native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant has narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often aromatic, similar to rosemary, hence its common name. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and prefers partial to full sun. Rhexia rosmarinoides is often found in wetlands, swamps, and along stream banks, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife.
